fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
If the permission is granted when username is in lower case, the permission does not work when the username changed to upper case

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a user "admin" in Bamboo internal directory
# Grant Admin permission to the user "admin" in Bamboo Global Permission
# Create a user "Admin" in Crowd internal directory
# Setup Crowd User Directory in Bamboo
# Set Crowd directory to be higher than Bamboo internal directory at Bamboo User Directories setting
# Check the granted permission at Bamboo Global Permissions

h3. Expected Results
The granted permission still works

h3. Actual Results
Bamboo Global Permissions list shows the user "Admin" instead of the lower case "admin" but the granted permissions are missing (the checkbox are not selected)

h3. Note
The same problem will happen if Bamboo internal directory have upper case group name "Test" while Crowd directory have lowercase "test"

h3. Workaround
# [Enforce lowercase username/groups|https://confluence.atlassian.com/crowd/enforcing-lower-case-usernames-and-groups-for-an-application-179446857.html] in Crowd server
# Synchronise Crowd directory in Bamboo
Bamboo will only get lowercase usernames/groups from Crowd server now
fields.summary: Username/group case changed breaks permission

fields.description:
Bamboo is currently not offered with any standard OS packaging, and makes life difficult for admins.

The SRPM linked below provides both an RPM spec file and init script for JIRA. Download the tar.gz file from Atlassian, place it in the SOURCES directory and build the RPMs using "rpmbuild -bb atlassian-bamboo.spec".

 https://github.com/minfrin/atlassian-rpms/blob/master/bamboo/atlassian-bamboo-6.10.6-1.el7.nosrc.rpm
fields.summary: [Patch] RPM support for Bamboo (v6.10.6)

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Currently there is no option to configure Content-Security-Policy header in Bamboo.
h3. Suggested Solution

Add an option to enable Content-Security-Policy header in Bamboo and configure its value.
h3. Workaround

There is no known workaround.
fields.summary: Add support for Content Security Policy

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Currently it is not possible to create global linked repositories using Bamboo Specs and have an end to end configuration as code approach - where no manual intervention is needed. Currently two manual steps are kinda required to have Bamboo Specs - a) create global linked repository and b) enable Scan repo for Bamboo Specs.
h3. Suggested Solution

Allow creation of a new linked repository via Bamboo Specs and option to enable Scan for the repo.
h3. Workaround

Could not find, just those manual steps are needed. There was a suggestion in BAM-18875 but does not seem to fully work.
fields.summary: Create global linked directory with repository-stored Bamboo Specs

fields.description:
h2. Problem Definition
At the moment, *both* log quiet time and build multiplier must be exceeded for a build hung event to be raised. It would be great to have greater control over this to enable which criteria you want to contribute.

Example: Only configuring the event to be raised if the build multipler is *4 regardless of log quiet period (perhaps due to a recursion problem that infinitely logs)

h2. Suggested Solution
Add checkboxes to allow choosing which criteria must be met to raise the hanging event.
fields.summary: Greater control over build monitoring configuration (build hang event)

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
If multiple artifact handlers have been specified for a build (eg. Remote artifact handler and S3 artifact handler) then there are two links created on the build results page. One that points to the *browse* endpoint and one that uses the *artifactUrlRedirect.action*.

{quote}
http://bamboo:8085/browse/PRJ-PLN-1/artifact/JOB/Test-Results/index.html
http://bamboo:8085/build/result/artifactUrlRedirect.action?planKey=PRJ-PLN-JOB&buildNumber=1&artifactName=Test%20Results
{quote}

The first link will download the artifact from the bamboo server. The second will download the artifact from whichever artifact handler is found first within the database. This feature is to ensure that the two links provided in the build results page obtain the artifact from the different artifact handlers.

Consider the use case where remote and S3 artifact handlers are used. The artifact is stored on the Bamboo server and on S3 storage. After 2 weeks the artifact on the Bamboo server is manually cleaned from the filesystem. S3 is used for long term storage.

From the Build results page we still see the two links however. The browse link will fail and the second link will produce inconsistent results. 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a plan that produces an artifact
# Enable both remote and s3 handlers
# Perform the build
# If the S3 handler artifact is the first on the artifacts tab, re-run the build until it becomes the second entry (check the hyperlink for artifactUrlRedirect)
# Once it's the second link, click it -- it'll still try and download from the filesystem. 

h3. Expected Results
No inconsistency depending on artifact handler order. The S3 artifact should be served from S3.

h3. Actual Results
If the s3 artifact handler is first, it serves from s3. If the s3 artifact handler is second, it serves from the Bamboo filesystem.

h3. Workaround
None
fields.summary: Artifact link (artifactUrlRedirect) behaves inconsistently depending on order of artifacts in the build when using multiple handlers

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
YAML can be configured with multiple repositories through [checkout task|https://docs.atlassian.com/bamboo-specs-docs/7.0.3/specs.html?yaml#task-repository-checkout]. However, trigger in YAML could not be configured to enable trigger for certain repository only. 

If a single repository is used to manage YAML Specs for multiple plans, a Specs change in a plan will trigger normal builds for all the related plans (if there are 50 plans affected, 50 builds will be added to the queue). This will flood the queue and will take some time for the agents to clear the queue.

h3. Suggested Solution
Configurable trigger setting in YAML so that only certain repository change will trigger the plan

h3. Workaround
Configure exclude function at {{Administration >> Linked repositories >> <repoName> >> Change detection options}} to exclude file pattern "bamboo-specs/.*"
fields.summary: Trigger repository configuration in YAML

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Currently, according to the documentation [Integrating Bamboo with LDAP|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/integrating-bamboo-with-ldap-289277210.html], the LDAP passwords are stored in Bamboo's database table CWD_DIRECTORY_ATTRIBUTE un-encrypted.
h3. Suggested Solution

The existing documentation recommends: 
{quote}To guarantee its security, you need to ensure that other processes do not have OS-level read permissions for this application's database or configuration files.
{quote}
 

For a better protection encrypt the credentials stored in the CWD_DIRECTORY_ATTRIBUTE table. 
h3. Workaround

There is no workaround.
fields.summary: Encrypt LDAP access credentials in the database

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Currently it is not possible to configure and enforce a password policy for the Bamboo internal user directory.
  
h3. Suggested Solution

Add an option in the Security settings to enable a custom password policy, for example via a regular expression.
h3. Workaround

There is no workaround. If password policy enforcement is mandatory then use an external user repository such as AD or Crowd.
fields.summary: Add a custom Password policy for Bamboo internal user directory

fields.description:
h3. Current situation
As of today, when Bitbucket Server and Bamboo are integrated, repositories can be created in Bamboo, and Bamboo users with correct permissions can access all repositories in Bamboo. This can present a security risk for companies that don't want this level of access. 

To workaround this situation, Bamboo administrators need to add an extra step for creating repositories that consist in:
- A Bamboo admin creating linked repositories, and restricting access to that repository. 
- A Plan admin that can use those linked repositories in the plan. 

This not only creates a dependency between administrators, it also doesn't cover the possibility to create plan repositories.

h3. Accepted solution 1

Have a new level of permissions at an Application Link level that restricts bamboo users/groups on which repositories (or repository projects) to access.

h3. Accepted solution 2

Have the possibility to inherit Bitbucket repository (or repository project) permissions in Bamboo, and use those permissions to restrict visibility to Bamboo Plan admins.
fields.summary: Improve permission granularity when it comes to integrating Bamboo and Bitbucket Server

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
When publishing an artifact, agent opens a socket before compressing the artifacts. If the compression step takes longer than the connector's configured connectionTimeout (default 20 seconds), the socket times out on the server end, and we cannot write to it when the compression finishes. This can occur with lots of files too during file scanning / directory traversal.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Set the connector's connectionTimeout to a low value
 # Create plan for a remote agent with a compressed artifact
 # Run the plan

h3. Expected Results
The artifact is published successfully

h3. Actual Results

The below exception is thrown in the agent logs:
{noformat}
simple	08-Apr-2020 11:38:20	Publishing an artifact: linux
error	08-Apr-2020 11:38:46	com.atlassian.bamboo.build.artifact.BambooRemoteArtifactHandler: java.net.SocketException: Broken pipe (Write failed)
error	08-Apr-2020 11:38:46	Unable to publish artifact [linux]: Unable to publish artifact Required shared artifact: [linux], pattern: [**/**] anchored at: [linux] for ART-BAM-JOB1-3 via com.atlassian.bamboo.build.artifact.BambooRemoteArtifactHandler@2d0a8b6d {noformat}

h3. Workaround

Set connectionTimeout in server.xml to a higher value. Example:
{noformat}
...
        <Connector
            port="443"
            maxThreads="150" minSpareThreads="25"

            connectionTimeout="120000"

            disableUploadTimeout="true"
...
{noformat}
fields.summary: Artifact publishing fails when compression takes longer than connectionTimeout

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Currently, Bamboo does not have an option that allows configuring how many agents (local, remote, and elastic) can be installed in the Bamboo instance.
h3. Suggestion

Add an option that allows configuring the limit of how many agents can be installed in Bamboo server.
fields.summary: Allow to restrict how many agents can be installed in Bamboo server

fields.summary: Provide API to listen test quarantine/resume events

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Bamboo logo and some icons (nav links, help, administration) are not vertically aligned well to the center. The help and administration mouse-over highlights also overshoot the bar which results in a shadowing that extends onto the page.

This is more apparent in Firefox but also affects Chrome.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Open Bamboo
# Mouse-over the help and administration icons.

h3. Expected Results
All nav bar elements are well vertically aligned to the center.

h3. Actual Results
 !bamboo-header.png!

h3. Workaround
Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Bamboo logo and some icons are not vertically aligned well to the center

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Starting from February 2020, Chrome version 80 (and later Firefox and IE as well) started enforcing different requirements on cross-site cookies:
 * The new secure-by-default model assumes all cookies should be protected from external access unless otherwise specified. Developers must use a new cookie setting, `_SameSite=None_`, to designate cookies for cross-site access.
 * With Chrome 80 will treat cookies that have no declared SameSite value as `_SameSite=Lax_` cookies.

Reference [https://blog.chromium.org/2019/10/developers-get-ready-for-new.html] for full details on the change in Chrome's behavior.
h3. Suggested Solution

Add a configuration option to Bamboo administration for `SameSite` policy (None, Lax, Strict) with a reasonable secure default.
h3. Workaround
 * Disable `SameSite` change at Chrome.
fields.summary: Add SameSite policy configuration option

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

After changes to Tomcat and Commons Daemon in the newer Tomcat that Bamboo uses (8.5.44 +), the default user is now Local Service. The following Apache issues describe the changes:
* https://bz.apache.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=55969
* https://bz.apache.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=63310

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Upgrade to Bamboo 7.0.2 or above on Windows using custom directories
# Reinstall the Service
# Do not update the Log On user
# Install the Service
# Start the Service

h3. Expected Results
Bamboo starts up as expected
h3. Actual Results
Bamboo application starts with a Bootstrap error caused by failing healthcheck. The service is unable to access the Bamboo Home directory files.

h3. Workaround

Update the Bamboo service to [run Bamboo as a Windows service as the local user|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/running-bamboo-as-a-windows-service-as-the-local-user-416580754.html].
fields.summary: Bamboo Windows Service defaults to logging on as Local Service

fields.description:
Over recent Bamboo releases (_v6.9 or above_), license count for Started License have changed, making difficult for users to make use of the product or to impose certain features in order to keep track of configuration. Due to that, Starter License should change allowing:
 * Number of Jobs: _Unlimited_
 * Number of local agents supported: _1_
 * Number of remote agents supported: _0_
fields.summary: Starter License should allow unlimited jobs with 1 local agent

fields.description:
Bamboo comes along with the concept of *global variables* which does represent only one type of variables in Bamboo. According to [Defining global variables|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/defining-global-variables-289277112.html] the concept behind is this:
{quote}Global variables are defined across your entire Bamboo instance, and have the same value for every plan that is built by Bamboo.
{quote}
(!) That said, this type of Bamboo variable permits sharing a key-value pair e.g. between plans, though *it allow to merely set and get of a fix value*.

(i) For sharing dynamic values between plans there exists the option of assigning those to keys and saving them in a file on source side, while extracting those per Bamboo's Inject variables task on destination side. However, that is somewhat onerous.

(on) Ideally, a global Bamboo variable would serve for this, so it may be setup right as described in the above KB and at defining it a value should be given (could be any) as it's now. But when using it per _${bamboo.<my variable>}_ from e.g. within a Bamboo Script task, *it should be possible to not only read it* (which is so now), *but also to write on it and thereby assign a a new value to this variable*.
fields.summary: Use of global Bamboo variables dynamically (not only for a fix value)
The Specs repository list shows a deleted repository.

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Specs repository links break for the nth repository and work fine for the first repository.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a Bamboo Project
 # Create 2 Linked repositories: test, test2
 # Enable Bamboo Specs for that repository in the Linked repository configuration
 # Go to Project settings page into "Bamboo Specs repositories" tab
 # Add the 2 linked repositories
 # Refresh the page with and look at the links for repositories

h3. Expected Results

The first repository link works ok and the nth repository works ok.
h3. Actual Results

The first repository link works ok
{noformat}
<base-url>/admin/configureLinkedRepositories.action?repositoryId=524289
{noformat}
The nth repository links fail
{noformat}
<base-url>/admin/configureLinkedRepositories.action/admin/configureLinkedRepositories.action?repositoryId=524289&repositoryId=43548673

{noformat}
h3. Workaround

Currently there is no workaround.
fields.summary: Specs repository Link broken

fields.description:
The GitHub repository configuration doesn't have the option to use any other authentication method other than *Username and Password.*

Add the functionality to use SSH keys to authenticate in GitHub.
fields.summary: GitHub repository type doesn't work with anything other than username/password

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Bamboo server log throws "Security framework of XStream not initialized, XStream is probably vulnerable" message.

h3. Suggested Solution

Set the permissions for the XStream library when it is initialized and do not rely on the defaults. An explicit call to addPermission() would no longer log the warning.

h3. Workaround

There is no workaround.
fields.summary: Bamboo server log throws Security framework of XStream not initialized, XStream is probably vulnerable.

fields.summary: Internal Server Error instead of 404

fields.description:
Sometimes, we want to have different build configuration for different Bamboo instances (e.g. deployments on Bamboo instance #1 but no deployments on Bamboo instance #2)

However, this isn't possible with YAML Specs, because the same YAML file will be applied in both Bamboo instances. The only way to get this working is it use Java Specs, which isn't great for non-Java projects

It would be great to have the option to pick which YAML files Bamboo Specs should evaluate within `bamboo-specs` directory. So then each Bamboo server can look/parse different YAML files
fields.summary: Allow picking a particular file for Bamboo YAML Specs to parse

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Bamboo fails to communicate with SMTP servers using TLS. Reported issue:
 * com.atlassian.mail.MailException: javax.mail.MessagingException: Could not convert socket to TLS
 * javax.net.ssl.SSLHandshakeException: No appropriate protocol (protocol is disabled or cipher suites are inappropriate)

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Java 8u292+ and JDK 11.0.11+ in Bamboo 8+ - [Openssl had TLS 1.0 and 1.1 disabled|https://mail.openjdk.java.net/pipermail/jdk8u-dev/2021-April/013680.html]
 # Navigate as Bamboo Admin to _Cog >> Overview >> Mail server_.
 # Create or edit an existing configuration there and check the option "Use TLS".
 # Define Bamboo system or e.g. build notifications (for testing).

h3. Expected Results

Notifications sent out from Bamboo should be encrypted in TLS 1.2 since TLS 1.0 is well known for security vulnerabilities. 
h3. Actual Results

Check or filter the emails sent from Bamboo and find them encrypted in TLS 1.0.
h3. Workaround

Add the system property below:
{noformat}
-Dmail.smtp.ssl.protocols=TLSv1.2
{noformat}
Following [Configuring your system properties|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/configuring-your-system-properties-289277345.html]
fields.summary: Bamboo without TLS 1.2 select option for SMTP mail server configuration

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
When a deployment project is cloned, its release version is the same as the original deployment project. Our customers are facing an issue when they want to set a release version lower than the original release version. In this case, they need to manually change the release version of each deployment until the number reaches the original version.

h3. Suggested Solution
It should be a great idea that Bamboo has a feature to restart the release version.

h3. Workaround
# Execute this query to get the deployment project id.
{code:sql}
select deployment_project_id, *
from deployment_project dp
where dp.name = '[PROJECT_NAME]'
{code}
 # With the result, now we are going to find the release version settings.
{code:sql}
select next_version_name, *
from deployment_version_naming dvn
where deployment_project_id = '[DEPLOYMENT_PROJECT_ID]'
{code}
 # Set the first release version with a number.
{code:sql}
update deployment_version_naming
set next_version_name = 'develop-1'
where deployment_project_id = '[DEPLOYMENT_PROJECT_ID]'
{code}
 # Create a new release on Bamboo. We will see the same name of the query and, in the next release, the number will be increased by one e.i test-2, test-3, test-4, etc.

*Note:* If the release version is already in use, Bamboo will show the following message "This release version is already in use, please select another.". Regarding this situation, we'll need to change it manually.
fields.summary: Restart the release version when a deployment project is cloned.

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

According to https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/bamboo-variables-289277087.html bamboo.shortPlanName should contain the name of the plan. In the case of deployment plans this variable contains the branch name (instead of the corresponding build plan name).
h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a script task that only contains echo ${bamboo.shortPlanName} in a deployment plan.
# Create a release from the master branch. The value of the bamboo.shortPlanName is the correct one, the name of the build plan.
# Create a release from another branch. The value of the bamboo.shortPlanName is the name of the branch instead of the name of the build plan.


h3. Expected Results

The variable value is the name of the plan.

h3. Actual Results

The variable value is the name of the branch.

h3. Workaround

There is no workaround.
fields.summary: shortPlanName contains branch name for deployments

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Currently, Bamboo supports the HotSpot variant of OpenJDK and OracleJDK only.

h3. Suggested solution

Add support for the OpenJ9 JVM from the AdoptJDK builds.

h3. Workaround 

There is no workaround.
fields.summary: Support AdoptJDK with OpenJ9 JVM

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Bamboo uses bundled Apache Maven to execute repository stored specs processing. It's 3 years old version and should be updated to latest 3.6.3
fields.summary: Update bundled Maven to 3.6.3

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
In Bamboo <6.9 you could:
# Run a build
# Have two jobs fail
# Disable a job
# Fix the other job
# Rerun failed jobs
# Build success
# Revisit the logs for the failed job that you disabled to try and fix it before re-enabling it.  The logs for the failed job still exists in the build result.

In Bamboo >6.9
# Run a build
# Have two jobs fail
# Disable a job
# Fix the other job
# Rerun failed jobs
# Build success
# However, the disabled job no longer exists in the build result and you cannot review the failure log anymore.

h3. Suggested Solution
Provide an option to keep these logs
h4. Why this is important 

# To release a new future we go through multiple plans, if one of the plans is misbehaving, the plans is disabled and we inspect logs to investigate the issue. With the log gone, there's no way to find what went wrong. 
# The logs are also used to help build parameters for the fix.
fields.summary: Provide option to retain logs for disabled failed job logs

fields.description:
h3. Current situation

Our [Bamboo variables documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/bamboo-variables-289277087.html] lacks clarity in the encryption topic.
h3. Accepted solution

Our document on [System-wide encryption|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/system-wide-encryption-873930114.html] mentions that
{quote}Variables that include keywords such as "secret" and "password". These variables will also be obfuscated in the UI
{quote}
This needs to be mentioned in the document on variables.

Apart from this, there are certain scenarios that are not clarified. To summarize them: if the variable name is edited, or re-saved without any changes, then the password must be input again, otherwise its value will not be the same as before.
fields.summary: Improve the variables documentation regarding encryption.

fields.description:

fields.description:
User can't create/modify Bitbucket Cloud repository

Bamboo reports Invalid username when try to save repository or click Test connection button
h3. Remark

(!) Check that the username provided as credentials for the repository is the username that can be found in Bitbucket settings > Account settings > Bitbucket profile settings in Bitbucket Cloud. 
 Because of GDPR-related changes to Bitbucket Cloud API the user email is not a valid value for the username field anymore and Bitbucket Cloud REST API dropped support of it recently.
h2. Workaround
h3. Bamboo 7.0.1 and above

Since Bamboo 7.0.1, the system property {{-Dbamboo.bitbucket.cloud.use.workspace.api=true}} can be added following [_Configuring your system properties_|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/configuring-your-system-properties-289277345.html] to enable usage of new Workspaces REST API of Bitbucket Cloud

h3. Recent versions
The following patches enable the Bitbucket Cloud Workspaces API:
* *6.10.5*: [^atlassian-bamboo-plugin-bitbucket-6.10.5-BAM-20900.jar]
* *6.9.2*: [^atlassian-bamboo-plugin-bitbucket-6.9.2-BAM-20900.jar]
* *6.8.3*: [^atlassian-bamboo-plugin-bitbucket-6.8.3-BAM-20900.jar] 

To install, please:
# Download the file for your version
# Stop Bamboo
# Move the file at {{<bamboo-install>/atlassian-bamboo/WEB-INF/atlassian-bundled-plugins/atlassian-bamboo-plugin-bitbucket-x.y.z.jar}} out of the {{<bamboo-install>}} directory
# Put the patch jar in {{<bamboo-install>/atlassian-bamboo/WEB-INF/atlassian-bundled-plugins/atlassian-bamboo-plugin-bitbucket-x.y.z-BAM\-20900.jar}}
# Start Bamboo


h3. Older Versions

If you are unable to upgrade at the moment, please configure Linked repositories of type "Git" or "Mercurial" to work around this issue.
fields.summary: Can't create/modify Bitbucket Cloud repository

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When a Plan Branch is created, the Quarantined Tests in the main plan (e.g. master), are not inherited, so the test is not put in quarantine in the newly created Plan Branches.

(i) This only affects plan created using Java _Specs_
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # create a plan using Java _Specs_
 # create a failed test
 # add the test to Quarantine
 # Create a Plan branch

h3. Expected Results

The Plan branch should inherit the Quarantined Test
h3. Actual Results

The Quarantined Test are not inherited
h3. Workaround

Manually add the failed test to Quarantine
fields.summary: Java Specs - Quarantined Tests not inherited by Plan Branch

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Upgrading Bamboo with LDAP configuration from 6.5.x or lower to the latest version will have error message

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Configure Bamboo 6.5.1 with LDAP configuration
 # Upgrade Bamboo to version 7.0.2

h3. Expected Results
The LDAP migration works without problem

h3. Actual Results
The below exception is thrown in the atlassian-bamboo.log file:

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Other Docker images (Confluence Server, Crowd, JIRA, Bitbucket) all explicit set the ENTRYPOINT to _tini_ within their corresponding Dockerfiles - removing the need for end-users to have to remember to specify that flag when standing up the container.

h3. Suggested Solution
It should be a great idea that our Bamboo Dockerfile sets ENTRYPOINT to _tini_.
fields.summary: Bamboo Dockerfile sets ENTRYPOINT to tini.

fields.description:
h3. Problem definition

Currently Bamboo doesn't provide an option to verify the integrity of the installation files that are downloadable from: [https://www.atlassian.com/software/bamboo/download-archives].
h3. Suggestion

Add a method for verifying the integrity of the downloads. One option would be SHA - \{1,256,512\}
checksums (preferably all) for the archives/install binaries together with a signature of the sums.
fields.summary: Provide SHA-256 checksums for the files on the Download page
Verify if NO_AUTO_VALUE_ON_ZERO mode is disabled during installation

fields.description:
h3. Background

In the big telcos there are some well separated responsibilities between teams, e.g. dev, CI/CD, and online ops. Unfortunately, you don't have control over their schedule and the real deployment looks like an async process and it takes 1-2 days. 

In this case a complete CI/CD or agile change-over is challenging. It is much more practical to take it in small steps.
h3. Suggestion

After a deployment start, should be possible to keep deployment in "In progress" or whatever state *without* any running process. After a successful _real_ deployment (which has been done by another team), a trigger could move it into "Done" state.
h3. Workaround for won't do resolution

Create some limited agents (local, or remote) with few resources and assign those to "long running real deployment checker tasks".
fields.summary: Allow deployment status "In Progress" without running tasks, and modification

fields.description:
Allow the same LDAP login credentials for bamboo to be used when authenticating to a Harbor docker registry configured using the same User directory. Essentially passing the same token used for Bamboo login to the custom registry, maybe?

This would preclude the need for
 * one shared key per plan
 * OR one shared key for all plans
 * OR including a basic auth user for bamboo in the custom registry, which essentially defeats the purpose of LDAP binding in the first place.
fields.summary: Passing LDAP credentials between Bamboo and Docker task
Programmatically removing branch from 3rd party plugin, can remove stages and jobs from master plan.

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
In the *Project Settings*, there are two menus related to permissions called *Project permissions* and *Plan permissions*, as shown in the image below:
!Screen Shot 2020-04-06 at 18.45.34.png|thumbnail! 

Despite these functionalities, there are no menus related to Deployment Project permissions and Deployment Environment permissions on this page. Therefore, the users should configure these permissions manually in each deployment of the project instead of setting them up in one place and reflecting them across all deployments.

h3. Suggested Solution
It should be a great idea that Bamboo has two menus within the *Project settings*, in which they will manage the global permission for Deployment Project and Deployment Environment.
fields.summary: Create two menus in the Project Settings feature
Allow Build Hang Config to be set in YAML bamboo specs

fields.description:
Currently Bamboo is offering Java and YAML Specs for the purpose of "configure by code".

There should be an additional option e.g. on the plan's configuration page under select button "Actions" to allow "Show plan as XML" which under the hood triggers a "View plan as Java Specs" action and a subsequent conversion of Java to XML.

Motivation for that can be:
 * XML is easier to convert compared to Java and YAML, thus compatibility with other tools can be improved.
 * For getting most Bamboo UI features, Java Specs is the better choice over YAML. Though for the sole purpose of configuring a build by code, learning Java is not the best option. However, XML is well known.
fields.summary: Provide plan configuration in XML format (not only Java and YAML)

fields.description:
To use the enhanced plan branch configuration in Bamboo 7.0, your code must be stored in Bitbucket Server and you must be using Bamboo Specs for plan configuration.

Current Case: 
 Enhanced plan branch Is supported for the Bitbucket server only.

Expected :
 It should be supported for SVN or Bitbucket Cloud or other non-Atlassian source control tools
fields.summary: Enhanced plan branch configuration for SVN or Git

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Running Deployment Project with Docker Container will have NPE at the end

h3. Steps to Reproduce

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Late build result arrival for a job that was marked incomplete due to the agent going offline and is now queued from a rebuild will cause the Build Activity dashboard to be unable to render.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a plan with two jobs
#* Job 1: Script Task: sleep30;
#* Job 2: Script Task: pwd;
# Dedicate Job 1 to a remote agent 1
# Dedicate Job 2 to another agent, doesn't matter what. Local is OK. It just needs to succeed.
# Start the plan
# Send *SIGSTOP* (kill -19) to remote agent 1 (running Job 1) wrapper and JVM processes to pause them (do this before sleep finishes)
# Wait for the agent to be registered offline and Job 1 to go gray, will occur within 10 minutes (but depends when the last heartbeat was sent)
# Rerun the same build
# Send *SIGCONT* (kill -18) to remote agent 1 (running Job 1) JVM processes and wrapper process to resume the process and allow it to finish processing the build
# Visit the *Builds > Build Activity* UI

h3. Expected Results
Build Activity dashboard renders

h3. Actual Results
Build activity dashboard *Building* and *Queued* sections are blank

The below exception is thrown in the *atlassian-bamboo.log* file:
{noformat}
2020-03-30 14:05:48,320 INFO [http-nio-8085-exec-12] [AccessLogFilter] bamboo GET http://localhost:8085/build/admin/ajax/getDashboardSummary.action?_=1585537548170 180357kb
....
2020-03-30 14:05:48,329 WARN [http-nio-8085-exec-12] [QueuedBuildJsonDecorator] Could not get CurrentlyBuilding for [SLEEP-SLEEP-2]
2020-03-30 14:05:48,330 ERROR [http-nio-8085-exec-12] [JsonStreamResult]
java.lang.NullPointerException: Entry removal semantics not supported (on messageType).
	at com.google.common.base.Preconditions.checkNotNull(Preconditions.java:895)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.struts.JsonStream.put(JsonStream.java:77)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.ww2.actions.build.AbstractBuildJsonDecorator.getBaseJson(AbstractBuildJsonDecorator.java:104)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.ww2.actions.build.QueuedBuildJsonDecorator.getJson(QueuedBuildJsonDecorator.java:108)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.ww2.actions.build.BuildJsonProviderAction.streamQueuedBuilds(BuildJsonProviderAction.java:180)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.ww2.actions.build.BuildJsonProviderAction.streamJson(BuildJsonProviderAction.java:154)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.ww2.actions.build.DashboardSummaryAction.streamJson(DashboardSummaryAction.java:12)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.struts.JsonStreamResult.execute(JsonStreamResult.java:35)
	at com.opensymphony.xwork2.DefaultActionInvocation.executeResult(DefaultActionInvocation.java:375)
	at com.opensymphony.xwork2.DefaultActionInvocation.invoke(DefaultActionInvocation.java:279)
	at com.opensymphony.xwork2.interceptor.DefaultWorkflowInterceptor.doIntercept(DefaultWorkflowInterceptor.java:181)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.ww2.interceptors.BambooWorkflowInterceptor.validateWorkflow(BambooWorkflowInterceptor.java:36)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.ww2.interceptors.BambooWorkflowInterceptor.doIntercept(BambooWorkflowInterceptor.java:20)
	at com.opensymphony.xwork2.interceptor.MethodFilterInterceptor.intercept(MethodFilterInterceptor.java:99)
	at com.opensymphony.xwork2.DefaultActionInvocation.invoke(DefaultActionInvocation.java:249)
{noformat}

h3. Workaround

h6. Option 1
Restart Bamboo and the build activity dashboard will work again.

h6. Option 2
# Query the build queue API to find the phantom job causing the issue: {{$BAMBOO_BASE_URL/rest/api/latest/queue?expand=queuedBuilds}}
{code}
<queue expand="queuedBuilds">
<link href="$BAMBOO_BASE_URL/rest/api/latest/queue" rel="self"/>
<queuedBuilds expand="queuedBuild" start-index="0" max-result="1" size="1">
<queuedBuild planKey="SLEEP-SLEEP-JOB1" buildNumber="2" buildResultKey="SLEEP-SLEEP-JOB1-2">
<triggerReason>Rerun build</triggerReason>
<link href="$BAMBOO_BASE_URL/rest/api/latest/result/SLEEP-SLEEP-JOB1-2" rel="self"/>
</queuedBuild>
</queuedBuilds>
</queue>
{code}
# On a busy instance with lots of builds in the queue it might be hard to identify which JOB is the one causing the issue, so combine it with the error in the logs when accessing the dashboard:
{code}
2020-02-27 13:15:45,336 WARN [http-nio-8085-exec-846] [QueuedBuildJsonDecorator] Could not get CurrentlyBuilding for [SLEEP-SLEEP-2]
2020-02-27 13:15:45,336 ERROR [http-nio-8085-exec-846] [JsonStreamResult] 
java.lang.NullPointerException: Entry removal semantics not supported (on messageType).
	at com.google.common.base.Preconditions.checkNotNull(Preconditions.java:226)
{code}
# Once the job is identified, you can fix the dashboard by deleting the queued job via REST using the build key from the Queue API. Example below:
{code}
BAMBOO_BASE_URL=http://localhost:8085
BAMBOO_ADMIN_USER=bamboo
BUILD_RESULT_KEY=SLEEP-SLEEP-JOB1-2
curl --user $BAMBOO_ADMIN_USER -X DELETE "$BAMBOO_BASE_URL/rest/api/latest/queue/$BUILD_RESULT_KEY"
{code}
fields.summary: Late build result arrival for a job that was marked incomplete and is now queued will cause the Build Activity dashboard to be unable to render

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Bamboo has a suboptimal query for to get deployed versions for Jira issue which occurs from this API call:
* $BAMBOO_BASE_URL/rest/api/latest/deploy/issue-status/$ISSUE_KEY

Its runtime compounds as deployment results increase and runtimes have been observed over 30 minutes. This can cause high CPU usage on the database and exhaustion of database connections should a sufficient amount of requests to the API be active concurrently on the Bamboo side.

With 12000 deployment results the query will take 1 minute to complete on MySQL and 15 seconds on PostgreSQL.

This is the query:
{code}
select mutabledep1_.DEPLOYMENT_VERSION_ID as DEPLOYME1_64_, mutabledep1_.NAME as NAME2_64_, mutabledep1_.CREATED_DATE as CREATED_3_64_, mutabledep1_.AGE_ZERO_POINT as AGE_ZERO4_64_, mutabledep1_.CREATOR_USERNAME as CREATOR_5_64_, mutabledep1_.PLAN_BRANCH_NAME as PLAN_BRA6_64_, mutabledep1_.PROJECT_ID as PROJECT_7_64_, mutabledep1_.VARIABLE_CONTEXT_BASELINE_ID as VARIABLE8_64_ from DEPLOYMENT_RESULT mutabledep0_ inner join DEPLOYMENT_VERSION mutabledep1_ on mutabledep0_.VERSION_ID=mutabledep1_.DEPLOYMENT_VERSION_ID where (mutabledep0_.ENVIRONMENT_ID in (select mutableenv2_.ENVIRONMENT_ID from DEPLOYMENT_ENVIRONMENT mutableenv2_ where mutableenv2_.PACKAGE_DEFINITION_ID=?)) and mutabledep0_.QUEUED_DATE=(select max(mutabledep3_.QUEUED_DATE) from DEPLOYMENT_RESULT mutabledep3_ where mutabledep3_.ENVIRONMENT_ID=mutabledep0_.ENVIRONMENT_ID and mutabledep3_.LIFE_CYCLE_STATE<>'NotBuilt')
{code}

It has been observed to affect both PostgreSQL and MySQL.  However, MySQL performance is roughly 4x worse than PostgreSQL.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a number of deployment environments and have a large amount of deployment results
# Link one of the environments to a Jira issue by deploying a build with a linked issue
# Hit the API for that issue: $BAMBOO_BASE_URL/rest/api/latest/deploy/issue-status/$ISSUE_KEY

h3. Expected Results
The executes in a timely fashion.

h3. Actual Results
The query runs for a very long time depending on dataset and DBMS.

Truncated stack of running thread in Bamboo 6.6.2:
{noformat}
"http-nio-8085-exec-10" #31 daemon prio=5 os_prio=0 tid=0x00007f8cac005000 nid=0x3a runnable [0x00007f8c8faef000]
   java.lang.Thread.State: RUNNABLE
	at java.net.SocketInputStream.socketRead0(Native Method)
...
	at org.postgresql.jdbc.PgPreparedStatement.executeQuery(PgPreparedStatement.java:117)
	at com.mchange.v2.c3p0.impl.NewProxyPreparedStatement.executeQuery(NewProxyPreparedStatement.java:353)
	at org.hibernate.engine.jdbc.internal.ResultSetReturnImpl.extract(ResultSetReturnImpl.java:71)
...
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.deployments.versions.persistence.DeploymentVersionDaoImpl.findLatestKnownVersionsForEnvironmentsOfDeploymentProject(DeploymentVersionDaoImpl.java:448)
...
	at com.sun.proxy.$Proxy968.findLatestKnownVersionsForEnvironmentsOfDeploymentProject(Unknown Source)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.rest.deployments.issues.JiraIssueRelatedDeploymentsResource.getJiraIssueStatusForProject(JiraIssueRelatedDeploymentsResource.java:128)
...
	at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:748)
{noformat}

h3. Workaround

h6. Workaround 1
Expire some deployment results by configuring it at *Bamboo Administration >> Overview >> Expiry*
* [Configuring global expiry|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/configuring-global-expiry-289277253.html]

h6. Workaround 2
*For PostgreSQL only*.
Create the below index on your Bamboo database:
{code}
CREATE INDEX
    dr_queued_env_lc
ON
    deployment_result
USING
    btree
    (
        queued_date,
        environment_id,
        life_cycle_state
    );
{code}
(!) The equivalent index does not seem to improve performance on MySQL. The optimiser still prefers an unindexed route. You can still try it since it depends heavily on the version of MySQL and table statistics but our testing has shown little improvement even when the index is forced.

h6. Workaround 3
Jira can sometimes hit this API over the application link which will trigger the query, so if the integration and features provided by it are not needed by you or this issue causes crippling problems in Bamboo -- you may opt to remove the application link between Bamboo and Jira. Users and other automations may trigger this API outside of Jira though.
fields.summary: Long running query to get deployed versions for Jira issue

fields.description:
When you define a "Bitbucket Cloud" repo, you have to choose the branch from a drop-down menu of available branches, like this:
 !image-2020-03-25-10-31-13-469.png|small! 

This is not very flexible compared to a "Git" type repo, where the branch can be specified via a variable:

 !image-2020-03-25-10-33-15-755.png|small! 

Our use case is that we have a project with multiple "stable" branches that each need their own CI plan, let's call these "1.x", "2.x", "3.x", and "4.x". We also have master for new work, of course. So at the moment in Bamboo, if we want to use the "Bitbucket Cloud" repo type, we need to define five separate repos, one for each stable branch plus master. But if that repo type allowed the branch to be a variable instead of a literal, we could cut this down to one repo definition and simply change the value of that variable within each build plan, like we can if we use the "Git" repository type. Cutting down from five repos to one doesn't sound like much, but when you manage over 30 projects, each with their own array of stable branches, this all adds up to a huge list of repo definitions and a lot of duplicated configuration.

We could work around this by switching from the "Bitbucket Cloud" repo type to the plain old "Git" repo type, but then we'd lose all the nice features of the former, like automatic publication of build results to Bitbucket Cloud.
fields.summary: Allow branch of Bitbucket Cloud repo to be specified by a variable

When the plan doesn't have an agent responsible for performing its tasks due to lack of capability. Today, Bamboo show this follow message "No agent can build this job", and the plan can be executed; however, it remains in the queue until it is removed manually.

Regarding this situation, Bamboo should show a message asking for an agent who has a capability for that plan. Also, the plans should not be carried out.

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Group configuration is not anymore working for groups with "/" forward slashes

Bamboo doesn't allow modifying groups with some special characters like "/", but they can be created in Bamboo, LDAP or JIRA for example.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Add a group called "name/name" in Bamboo
 # Try to navigate to the Bamboo group permissions page.

h3. Expected Results

The permissions can be configured
h3. Actual Results

The Browser will receive a 400 error for the following request:
{noformat}
Request URL: http://localhost:8085/rest/api/latest/admin/groups/test%2Fgroup/more-members?_=1585011445030
Request Method: GET
Status Code: 400 
Remote Address: [::1]:80
{noformat}
The following dialog will show up:
 !Screen Shot.png|thumbnail!
h3. Note
 * This problem is reproduced in Bamboo 7.0.2
 * This issue is probably affecting other characters (it is also present for the backslash for example)

h3. Work Around
 * To delete a group, first open the group's page and then delete from the top right hand corner.
 * To add or remove users, you will need to navigate to the user and add/remove the user to group from there
fields.summary: Group configuration is not working for groups with "/" forward slashes

The branch plan drop-down button does not differentiate between enabled and disabled branches as older Bamboo versions.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Install Bamboo 7.0.1.
 # Access any plan that contains branches and disable any branch.
 # Click on the drop-down button in the plan branch.

h3. Expected Results

Bamboo should differentiate between enabled and disabled branches as older Bamboo versions:

(i) Enabled branches are shown in blue and at the top of the list and disabled branches are shown in gray at the bottom of the list.
h3. !image-2020-03-19-15-52-11-412.png|width=518,height=334!  
h3. Actual Results

In Bamboo 7.0.1, all the branches are shown in gray color:

  !image-2020-03-19-15-51-48-131.png|width=409,height=202!

!image-2020-03-19-15-51-04-538.png|width=415,height=357!
h3. Workaround

Currently, there's no workaround.

Currently, Bamboo Server supports PostgreSQL up to:

(/) PostgreSQL 9.5

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
If we have many projects and defined multiple plan permission under permissions, there is no option to bulk update project permission and plan permission under 'Project settings'.

h3. Suggested Solution
Introduce Bulk edit option for modifying project level permission like project permission and plan permission.

h3. Why this is important
If there are hundreds of projects, it is hard to bulk modify plan permissions for all these projects indvidually.

h3. Workaround
* Use Bulk edit plan permission to modify/define plan level permission.
* Or edit project level permissions manually by going through each and every project.
fields.summary: Bulk edit for Project level permission

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

On Windows OS, starting up Bamboo 7.0.1 as service fails.
h3. Steps to Reproduce

The issue can be reproduced for a fresh Bamboo 7.0.1 installation on Windows and also for a Bamboo upgrade to Bamboo 7.0.1 on Windows.

For Bamboo upgrade (from e.g. 6.10.4 which runs as Windows service):
 # Shutdown the running Bamboo service
 # Upgraded Bamboo to 7.0.1. That works fine including uninstalls the existing Bamboo 6.10.4 service.
 # Navigated to Bamboo installation directory and run InstallAsService.bat. That fails with the following error message:
{noformat}
Neither the BAMBOO.exe file nor the Bamboo.exe file was found...
 Either the CATALINA_HOME environment variable is not defined correctly or the
incorrect service name has been used.
 Both the CATALINA_HOME environment variable and the correct service name are
required to run this program.
{noformat}

An new installed Bamboo 7.0.1 or an upgraded Bamboo 7.0.1 launched via _start-bamboo.bat_, so run as a process on Windows works as expected.
h3. Expected Results

Bamboo can be started and runs as expected once being started as a Windows service.
h3. Actual Results

The above error appears in Bamboo log and Bamboo will not start as Windows service.
h3. Workaround

If available, file _service.bat_ from Bamboo 6.10.4 can be used instead of the one being part of Bamboo 7.0.1.
fields.summary: Launching Bamboo 7.0.1 as Windows service fails

fields.description:

Currently there's no way to see only deployments activity in Bamboo.

Please add deployment activity on Bamboo.

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
As administrator I would like to have the ability to globally disable quiet periods

Quiet periods can be set up to a point where can significantly affect overall performance in Bamboo _(https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-20247)_.
fields.summary: As administrator I would like to have the ability to globally disable quiet periods

In Bamboo, we can currently add an Amazon EC2 as an elastic agent; however, we don't have the same functionality for Microsoft Azure.

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Bambo does not currently have a User migration functionality like JIRA
* https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiraserver/migrating-users-between-user-directories-938847059.html
In a case where Bamboo internal Directory was previously used to manage users and groups, there is a need to be able to migrate these users and groups to other Atlassian Product for management

h3. Suggestion
Functionality to migrate users and groups to other Atlassian products

h3. Workaround

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Email/queue notification threads keep running / trying to send emails even after SMTP server is blocking the account sending emails. 
h3. Suggested Solution
After an X number of errors / exceptions within a 1 minute / hour, terminate email queue job until issue is resolved
h4. Why this is important 
When the SMTP isn't working / exception occurs, Bamboo will keep retrying non stop generating a lot of logs and hits to the SMTP service.
fields.summary: Stop notification emails after # of exceptions

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

The credentials table keeps shared credential definitions in Bamboo. For credentials_id field the values larger than 2,147,483,647 some functionality would fail.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a shared credentials entry with the ID value larger than 2,147,483,647. (These ID values are typically created by hibernate so one may have to manually adjust the credentials_id attribute value.)
 # Create a task that can use shared credentials, for example the SCP task. In the configuration of the task attempt to use the shared credentials selector.

h3. Expected Results

The task configuration succeeds.
h3. Actual Results

A validation error message in the UI similar to: Can't find shared credentials by ID: 2154790914.
h3. Workaround

There is no workaround.
fields.summary: Credentials_id range above 2,147,483,647 breaks credentials selectors

Use Java Specs

Can't install Bamboo from Windows installer if only AdoptJDK is available at environment
h3. Steps to Reproduce

It's possible to install Bamboo

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Build result shows as INCOMPLETE in Jira Development Summary
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # create a project in Jira with some issues (eg. ST-1, ST-2)
 # create a plan in Bamboo with a Job that uses a label to link result to a Jira issue 
 # Run plan in the following order:
 ** successful execution of the Job with link to issue ST-1
 *** build status in Jira will be displayed correctly
 ** +failed+ execution of the Job with link to issue ST-2
 *** build status will be shown as UNKNOWN in Jira
 ** successful execution of the Job with link to issue ST-2
 *** build status will still be shown as UNKNOWN in Jira

h3. Workaround
 # Perform a full reindex in Bamboo (*Administration > System > Indexing > Perform a full reindex*).
 # follow the steps in the [Development panel shows incorrect Bamboo build or deployment summary|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jirakb/development-panel-shows-incorrect-bamboo-build-or-deployment-summary-981147396.html] to fix the issue in Jira server.
fields.summary: Build with result status show as Incomplete in JIRA

fields.description:
h2. Problem Definition
Any page that needs to calculate which agents can build something and includes offline agents, for example:
* Tasks
* Requirements
* Agent assignment (Deployments)

Can become non-performant as the amount of offline agents grows. This is a common pattern in instances where customers are spinning up and spinning down agents on demand without deleting them from Bamboo.

h2. Suggested Solution
When filtering offline agents, it might be sensible to filter out agents that have been offline for a certain time period. E.g. 6+ months.

h2. Workaround
Clean up offline agents that are no longer used at *Bamboo Administration >> Agents > Offline Agents*

Bamboo 6.10.x and later has a REST API that can be used to automate the deletion:
https://docs.atlassian.com/atlassian-bamboo/REST/6.10.4/#d2e857.
fields.summary: Calculating executable agents should have some filtering for performance reasons

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When using Java-based Bamboo Specs, if your specs POM contains a {{project/dependencyManagement}} element before the regular {{project/dependencies}} element (i.e. in its correct position), then when Bamboo Specs attempts to build the sanitised POM for execution, it will insert the "dependencies" found within {{project/dependencyManagement}} instead of the actual dependencies from {{project/dependencies}}.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a Java-based Bamboo Specs project, where the POM contains a {{dependencyManagement}} element (e.g. import the Spring BOM).
 # Wait for Bamboo to execute the Specs via RSS.
 # The execution will fail with an error about {{import}} not being a valid scope. If you inspect the POM that Bamboo created (as seen in the log below), you will see that Bamboo copied the dependencies from the original POM's {{dependencyManagement}} section instead of from the {{project/dependencies}} section.

h3. Expected Results

Bamboo properly handles the presence of a {{dependencyManagement}} element.
h3. Actual Results

Bamboo treats the {{dependencies}} nested inside the {{dependencyManagement}} section as dependencies.

The message below appears in the {{spec-logs/<repoId>/<timestamp>_<commit-hash>.log}} file:
{noformat}
05-Mar-2020 14:19:31	Content of pom.xml used:
05-Mar-2020 14:19:31	<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="no"?><project xmlns="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0 http://maven.apache.org/maven-v4_0_0.xsd">
05-Mar-2020 14:19:31	    <!--Edit template at BAMBOO_INSTALL/atlassian-bamboo/WEB-INF/classes/bamboo-specs-pom.xml-->
05-Mar-2020 14:19:31	    <modelVersion>4.0.0</modelVersion>
05-Mar-2020 14:19:31	    <parent>
05-Mar-2020 14:19:31	        <groupId>com.atlassian.bamboo</groupId>
05-Mar-2020 14:19:31	        <artifactId>bamboo-specs-parent</artifactId>
05-Mar-2020 14:19:31	        <version>6.10.4</version>
05-Mar-2020 14:19:31	        <relativePath/>
05-Mar-2020 14:19:31	    </parent>
05-Mar-2020 14:19:31	
05-Mar-2020 14:19:31	    <artifactId>bamboo-specs-generator</artifactId>
05-Mar-2020 14:19:31	    <version>1.0.0</version>
05-Mar-2020 14:19:31	    <packaging>jar</packaging>
05-Mar-2020 14:19:31	    <dependencies>
05-Mar-2020 14:19:31	            <dependency>
05-Mar-2020 14:19:31	                <groupId>org.springframework</groupId>
05-Mar-2020 14:19:31	                <artifactId>spring-framework-bom</artifactId>
05-Mar-2020 14:19:31	                <version>5.2.4.RELEASE</version>
05-Mar-2020 14:19:31	                <type>pom</type>
05-Mar-2020 14:19:31	                <scope>import</scope>
05-Mar-2020 14:19:31	            </dependency>
05-Mar-2020 14:19:31	        </dependencies>
05-Mar-2020 14:19:31	    <build>
05-Mar-2020 14:19:31	        <plugins>
05-Mar-2020 14:19:31	            <plugin>
05-Mar-2020 14:19:31	                <groupId>org.apache.maven.plugins</groupId>
05-Mar-2020 14:19:31	                <artifactId>maven-compiler-plugin</artifactId>
05-Mar-2020 14:19:31	                <configuration>
05-Mar-2020 14:19:31	                    <compilerArgs>
05-Mar-2020 14:19:31	                        <compilerArg>-proc:none</compilerArg>
05-Mar-2020 14:19:31	                    </compilerArgs>
05-Mar-2020 14:19:31	                </configuration>
05-Mar-2020 14:19:31	            </plugin>
05-Mar-2020 14:19:31	        </plugins>
05-Mar-2020 14:19:31	    </build>
05-Mar-2020 14:19:31	</project>
05-Mar-2020 14:19:31	Processing Specs within Docker container
{noformat}
h3. Workaround

The workaround is to avoid having a {{<dependencyManagement>}} element in the POM. Maybe putting it after the {{<dependencies>}} element would also work, but this is a non-canonical location, and this change might be "corrected" by an eager colleague putting things in their correct order or simply by someone running {{mvn tidy:pom}}, which also restores the canonical order of POM elements.

*Actual bug*

The bug is [here|https://stash.atlassian.com/projects/BAM/repos/bamboo/browse/components/bamboo-import-export/src/main/java/com/atlassian/bamboo/configuration/external/MavenSanitizerImpl.java#40]; the XPath expression being used to find the dependencies is too lenient. Maybe changing it to {{/project/dependencies}} would more accurately locate only the desired element.
fields.summary: Using dependencyManagement with RSS causes real dependencies to be lost

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
When jobs have no "Source Code Checkout" task and the build has been triggered automatically, the build activity page shows 'Anonymous user' instead of the user who performed the build. This causes a misunderstanding for users.

 !Screen Shot 2020-03-03 at 15.33.59.png|thumbnail!

h3. Suggested Solution
When there is this scenario, Bamboo should show the user that has made the latest commit.

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
System error links for deployments point to the wrong URL to browse the result

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a deployment with a SCP task
# Point it to a host that will timeout, e.g. 1.1.1.1
# Start the deploy
# Stop the deploy immediately
# Visit *Bamboo Administration >> System errors*
# Click the hyperlink for the deployment ID

h3. Expected Results
You're taken to the deployment result page with the logs and errors.

h3. Actual Results
{code}
An unexpected error has occurred
Could not find the '249298945-249397249' build
{code}

The below warning is shown in the atlassian-bamboo.log file:
{noformat}
2020-03-03 14:08:09,491 WARN [http-nio-8085-exec-17] [PlanAwareInterceptor] Action 'com.atlassian.bamboo.build.ViewBuild@5e28bdea' is plan aware but no plan can be found. PlanKey was '249298945-249397249'
{noformat}

h3. Workaround
# Click *View Error Log* 
# Take the final number in the hyperlink. E.g. In the link
{quote}
*Build 249298945-249397249 259162116* : Error occurred while executing the build for ...
{quote}
take *259162116* and insert it into the below URL to access the deployment result:
#* {{$BAMBOO_BASE_URL/deploy/viewDeploymentResult.action?deploymentResultId=259162116}}
fields.summary: System error links for deployments point to the wrong URL to browse the result

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Bamboo fails to ignore spaces at the end of the "bamboo.home" value in the bamboo-init.properties file.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
In the file bamboo-init.properties add some spaces at the end, for example:
{noformat}
bamboo.home=/home/temp/home                          
{noformat}

h3. Expected Results
Spaces will be removed or ignored. 

h3. Actual Results
Spaces are ignored for all folders but "jms-store". This will creates two home folders:
- One without spaces, with all the content *but* "jms-store".
- One with spaces, with the folder "jms-store" inside. 

h3. Workaround

Fix the file bamboo-init.properties by removing the spaces.
fields.summary: Bamboo fails to ignore spaces at the end of the "bamboo.home" value in the bamboo-init.properties file

fields.description:

h3. Steps to Reproduce

{code:java}
JAVA_OPTS="-Datlassian.mail.senddisabled"
{code}
 # Start Bamboo

h3. Expected Results

Bamboo should show something like this:
{code:java}
[InitialiseSmackOnStartup] Initialising IM servers...
[BambooSmackClient] No IM server specified. Bamboo Smack client not initialised.
{code}
h3. Actual Results

The below exception is thrown in the atlassian-bamboo.log file:
{code:java}
2020-02-20 16:26:12,877 INFO [AtlassianEvent::0-BAM::EVENTS:pool-1-thread-3] [InitialiseSmackOnStartup] Initialising IM servers...
2020-02-20 16:26:12,880 ERROR [AtlassianEvent::0-BAM::EVENTS:pool-1-thread-3] [InitialiseSmackOnStartup] Bamboo IM server client failed to startup.
java.lang.NullPointerException
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.xmpp.BambooSmackClient.getMessagingServerDefinition(BambooSmackClient.java:100)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.xmpp.BambooSmackClient.connect(BambooSmackClient.java:78)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.xmpp.InitialiseSmackOnStartup.handleEvent(InitialiseSmackOnStartup.java:26)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:62)
	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43)
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:498)
	at com.atlassian.event.internal.SingleParameterMethodListenerInvoker.invoke(SingleParameterMethodListenerInvoker.java:36)
	at com.atlassian.event.internal.AsynchronousAbleEventDispatcher$1$1.run(AsynchronousAbleEventDispatcher.java:46)
	at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1149)
	at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:624)

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When using Docker Runner, Bamboo ignores the container directory for the Docker script

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a plan with one job.
# (Optional) Create a script task to print information. For example:
{noformat}
echo PRINT WORKING DIR
echo ${bamboo.working.directory}
echo END
{noformat}
# Under "Docker", choose "Docker container". For the image, choose one. For example: "ubuntu:latest".
# Under volumes, change the default working directory mapping. For example, "Container directory" will now be set "/tmp".
# Run the build.

h3. Expected Results
Bamboo will use "/tmp" as the default working directory inside the container. This will also be reflected on the script <temp-path>/runInDockerXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX.sh 

h3. Actual Results

When runInDockerXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX.sh is created, it uses the working directory defined in the cfg.xml file (the file name varies depending on which type of agent is being used), ignoring the mapping set before. 

This will show in the build log in the following way:
{noformat}
command	20-Feb-2020 10:35:16	Beginning to execute external process for build 'pr - pl - Default Job #14 (PR-PL-JOB1-14)'\n ... running command line: \n/home/user/Downloads/temp/atlassian-bamboo-6.10.4/temp/runInDocker2459302165546153494.sh /home/user/Downloads/temp/home6104/temp/PR-PL-JOB1-14-ScriptBuildTask-4935773693336676544.sh\n ... in: /home/user/Downloads/temp/atlassian-bamboo-6.10.4/temp\n
error	20-Feb-2020 10:35:17	/tmp/runInDocker1413274602186967516.sh: 2: cd: can't cd to /home/user/Downloads/temp/home6104/xml-data/build-dir/PR-PL-JOB1
build	20-Feb-2020 10:35:17	PRINT WORKING DIR
build	20-Feb-2020 10:35:27	/home/user/Downloads/temp/home6104/xml-data/build-dir/PR-PL-JOB1
build	20-Feb-2020 10:35:27	END
{noformat}

h3. Workaround

Use the default value in the "Container directory" field, which is ${bamboo.working.directory}
fields.summary: When using Docker Runner, Bamboo ignores the container directory for the Docker script

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Admin Repository Settings page load of a long time if there are a huge number of build plans and repositories

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create around 1600 build plans (including branch plans)
# Create around 450 unique GIT URL Linked/Plan Repositories
The repository URL have to be valid and used in build plan to produce Git cache in Bamboo Home
# Access Repository Settings page at {{Administration >> Build Resources >> Repository Settings}}

h3. Expected Results
It load immediately

h3. Actual Results
It took about 5 minutes to load the page

h3. Workaround
If Mercurial repository isn't used in Bamboo, the add-on "Atlassian Bamboo Mercurial Repository Plugin" can be disabled at {{Administration >> Add-ons >> Manage Add-ons >> System add-ons}} to reduce the loading time
fields.summary: Admin Repository Settings page load for a long time

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Once VCS_LOCATION primary key surpasses 32bit int, Source code checkout task cannot be added or edited on deployment plans.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# When vcs_location_id reaches 2,147,483,648 (max int + 1), edit a deployment plan
# Attempt to add and save a source-code checkout task (or view an existing one)

h3. Expected Results
Source-code checkout task can be added.

h3. Actual Results
An error is shown in the UI upon hitting save:
*For input string: "2548170753"* (where the # is the ID of the repository)

No exception is found in the atlassian-bamboo.log.

h3. Workaround

The only workaround is to modify or add the source-code checkout via Bamboo Specs instead of the UI.

# Export the deployment project as a Bamboo Spec: *Edit Deployment Project >> ... >> View Project as Bamboo Spec*
# Take the exported spec and create a Bamboo Specs project using that code: [Tutorial: Create a simple plan with Bamboo Java Specs|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/tutorial-create-a-simple-plan-with-bamboo-java-specs-894743911.html]
# Add or modify the Source-code checkout task. Example:
{code}
...
            .environments(new Environment("QA")
                    .tasks(new CleanWorkingDirectoryTask(),
                        new ScriptTask()
                            .inlineBody("pwd;"),
                            new VcsCheckoutTask()
                            .checkoutItems(new CheckoutItem()
                                    .repository(new VcsRepositoryIdentifier()
                                            .name("linked-repository-name")))));
...
{code}
# Push the spec to the server:
{code}
mvn -Ppublish-specs
{code}
fields.summary: Source code checkout task cannot be added or edited on deployment plans, once VCS_LOCATION primary key surpasses 32bit int

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Currently Bamboo waits on Agents for build and agent status updates. Builds can become hung and agents can fail without the Bamboo server knowing until it is restarted.

h3. Suggested Solution

Add the functionality for the Bamboo server to poll the agents to check-in on the build and agent status as an option.
 
h3. Workaround 
Configure a [hanging build event|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/configuring-the-hanging-build-event-289277188.html] to catch hung builds.
fields.summary: Add Bamboo server agent polling for hung build detection and agent failure
